review_title: School with a good mission but poor organization and high burnout/staff turnover
pros: NLU values diversity in its employees and students and provides programs that would otherwise be inaccessible to students which is a great mission.
cons: NLU has grown exponentially, especially the undergraduate college, which is great! However, the systems in place are not equipped to handle this which leads to employee burnout and high turnover, as well as frustrated and confused students. There is constant communication issues between departments and I had no onboarding plan in place when I started.

pros: Do not have anything positive to say

pros:
NLU as an organization is one that truly cares for it's colleagues.

There are monthly kudos by the president for folks doing amazing things on campus and in their personal lives outside of work. 

There are a number of work groups to belong to where you can share your feedback, ideas and have those vetted. Leadership is constantly looking for ways share and reward at all levels of the university. This university truly cares for it's own and strives to create opportunities.

NLU is a hub for collaborative thought leaders looking to make an impact in the community.

It is easy to find mentors and just as easy to mentor others. The community is very welcoming.

There is plenty of opportunity for professional development, academic advancement and career advancement
cons: NLU, like many organizations and universities is limited by resources available. I will say that unlike other organizations, the students and employees of NLU come first when it comes to expensing those resources.

I'm still fairly new (under 2 years), so only time will tell. I guess salary is nothing to brag about. Salary for assistant professors is pretty low compared to other universities in the area.

review_title: Run as fast as you can
pros: The only pros of working here are if you can find relationships with decent people in a pile of literal garbage humans.
cons: Everything. From the first second i started, it was horrible and tense. They switched my position 3x for with no discussion or consent from myself. I was literally not a part of the conversation. They switched my offices 5x and we also switched Chicago neighborhoods. People there are all about money and survival. Everyone fighting for respect they will never ever get from upper management.

pros: Decent pay for Academic Advising
cons: 60% of the work is appeasing the higher-ups via reports and CONSTANT outreach to students, even if they are FINE. Followed by meetings where you are constantly asked to do more and held accountable for not doing the other stuff fast enough.

pros: The students are awesome and the work is rewarding
cons: They're trying but there are still strong sexist and racist undertones to their hiring, salary, and other policies

pros: Culture is very supportive and caring, work is meaningful and the university responds quickly to issues in curriculum and/or processes.

pros: The people here are great. They care about the work and their team members.

pros: Nice place to work over all

job_title: Student Success Advisor in Chicago, IL
pros: Great colleagues and the locations

pros: Employees enjoy the university's culture.
cons: Pay isn't the best and work is a bit boring.

review_title: Less academic and more corporate with each passing day
pros: Little micromanagement, good work-life balance with standard hours, the Chicago campus is in a good central location in the Loop, friendly colleagues that are genuinely good people and an overall strong sense of community. Your colleagues here are easily approachable and everyone will pitch in to help you get your work done. "That's not in my job description" is a phrase you'll rarely hear from anyone.
cons: The new management team values enrollment numbers and money over education. Immediate supervisors have little knowledge of workers' abilities and often give inconsistent and confusing performance feedback. There is little-to-no room for advancement unless you change departments or campus. Since the new president took over, there have been increased lay-offs and frequent staff departures. The university is slowly adopting a "for profit" mentality, creating a more corporate atmosphere, which is a departure from the institution's former academic feel. Supervisors seem to have little interest in their employee's career growth and aspirations.

review_title: Demoralizing and antithesis of what education should be
pros: Wonderful colleagues, supportive staff, great faculty
cons:
Mismanaged at every level starting at the very top. Poor culture driven by profits and enrollment. Those in power are out of touch with what learning actually means. They throw words around like student learning and student success to justify their agendas which is to bring in anyone with a pulse and to keep them there even if it means bending the academic honesty policy. 

Every negative comment in the reviews align with my experiences. There is a strong facade to the university bolstered by its rich history, but when you've seen what goes on at the top and witnessed how those attitudes trickle down, it's clear that NLU has become a Nivine machine pumping students through like cattle.

pros: Staff works well with one another and most are very passionate about their students.
cons: Management seems to be out of touch with the needs of adult learner transfers.  They've put so much stock into their pathways program, they seem to treat the adult learners as an after thought and many are under-prepared to begin these programs.  Furthermore, NLU can come off as pretty predatory - much like the for-profits- when it comes  trying to get students to register to meet numbers.

review_title: It's good and hard at the same time
pros:
My supervisor and her boss are highly ethical, kind, and great motivators. I trust them and have learned a lot from them. I see that our overall management team is striving to develop more leaders like the two of them and build a more collaborative, supportive culture.

I am busy every day. For some people, that might be a Con, but I enjoy being highly engaged each day and the feeling of having accomplished a lot by the end of every day. 

The PTO and benefits are very good/competitive for area colleges and universities. This includes tuition benefits after 6 months of employment.
cons:
As a staff member, you are expected to accomplish A LOT with very few resources. On top of the high expectations, the pay is mediocre. 

Honestly, for a non-profit university, this institution has very high turnover in its staff. That can make building a positive environment and culture of collegiality very difficult. And while *my* bosses are awesome, a lot of the upper management has been there for far too long and have so much pressure on them that they don't have enough time to invest in their employees. Nor do they have time for their own professional development, so their management/leadership styles can be less than inspiring. I know of a handful of staff members who specifically left due to the "bullying" style of an upper manager in the Enrollment Department who has been known to make people cry. 

They literally, really, actually will enroll anyone with a pulse. Doesn't exactly make you feel like you're contributing to something special when their admissions standards are so low.

pros: Accessible and convenient location, work two days per week, ID entry, multiple refrigerators and microwaves
cons: 10-week quarter system, ZOOM is overused, low faculty retention, poor adjunct pay, no say in the curriculum, little time to teach, students have papers due back-to-back, content meetings unuseful, instead of e-books, barely readable scanned readings are provided, Hakwes is used as a replacement for teaching, no computers in the classroom, teachers have to bring their own laptops, poor standards for students, students fail and repeat courses, no building from low-stakes to high-stakes assignments, no cafeteria, no free supplies, such as markers, for teachers, D2L is confusing for students, adjuncts make 16,000 per year

pros: There were some good colleagues that were willing to take their time to work with you.
cons: Lack of transparency within management. I quickly found out how the outreach and enrollment managers were less supportive of new team members and unwilling to invest in new resources to better support their goals. Management has been very shady in its communication and has been known to fire or force people to resign if they do not feel they are being "loyal to the NLU culture" which includes having to give standing ovations to each team member who speaks before and after, making sure you are sitting at the same lunch table as them, or pressuring other colleagues for potential gossip that can damage an employee's career there.

pros: Hmmm. Not much other than location in Chicago (right across from the Art Institute).
cons: The university keeps getting worse and worse. All you need is a pulse and the government's money and you will be admitted. No care anymore about quality of student. Terrible top management - condescending, unprofessional, out of touch with employees, never available to assist with work load and just pile more on to their employees. Toxic environment. No raises and very low pay.

pros: My coworkers and location of campus
cons: Can barely live of the salary.  Not even a cost of living raise two years in a row.  Manager is the worst I have ever had.  Controlling, condescending and demeaning.  Various complaints to HR and director about her and nothing done.

pros:
very pleasant, non-toxic atmosphere

Administrative staff not fairly compensated or appreciated.  Leadership gets the big bonuses and the support staff/professor gets the leftover peanuts!
